abstract.p: Lawrence Van Gelder column reports on symposium on proposed designs for reconstruction of Lower Manhattan at Cooper Union, art exhibition at Bruce Museum of Art and Science in Greenwich, Conn, concert at Society for Ethical Culture featuring songs Samuel Pepys and readings from his diary and selection of New York City Ballet and lighting designer Jennifer Tipton as first winners of Jerome Robbins Prize for excellence in dance art; photo (M)

block.p: Debating the Future Presented by the Architectural League, the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art and the Museum of Modern Art, the sold-out first part of a symposium on proposed designs for the reconstruction of Lower Manhattan will run from 4 to 10:30 p.m. today in the Great Hall at Cooper Union. Participants include members of the seven architectural firms chosen to submit plans for redesign of the World Trade Center site. The last part will be at Town Hall from 7 to 9 p.m. tomorrow. Admission there is free, but tickets are required. Some will be available at the door.

Going Public Tapping private collections in and around Greenwich, Conn., has yielded some of the greatest names in 20th-century art for an exhibition that opens on Saturday at the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich. The paintings of Beckmann, Chagall, Chuck Close (''Bill II,'' left), Duchamp, Lucian Freud, Magritte, Modigliani, Picasso, Rothko and Warhol, as well as the sculptures of Calder, Giacometti, Maillol and Moore are to be seen in ''Pleasures of Collecting: Part II, 20th-Century and Contemporary Art.'' The show continues through April 13.

Words and Music Samuel Pepys (1633-1703) didn't just keep a diary. He was an amateur composer, a singer and a keen observer of music in Restoration England; at 8 p.m. Friday at the Society for Ethical Culture, at 2 West 64th Street, he will be the inspiration for ''The Musical Life of Samuel Pepys.'' Presented by the New York Collegium, the evening will feature songs known to Pepys (including ''Beauty Retire'' by Pepys himself), as well as dramatized readings from his diary. The performance will be preceded by a screening of a recent conversation on Pepys between Andrew Parrott, music director of the Collegium, and Dr. Richard Luckett, curator of the Pepys Library at Cambridge University.

Winners The lighting designer Jennifer Tipton and the New York City Ballet have been named the first winners of the Jerome Robbins Prize for excellence in the dance arts. The awards of $100,000 each from the Jerome Robbins Foundation are to be presented tomorrow at the New York State Theater before an all-Robbins performance by the New York City Ballet with lighting by Ms. Tipton. . . . Exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art are among the winners of the annual awards of the United States section of the International Association of Art Critics. ''Gerhard Richter: 40 Years of Painting,'' organized by the Modern, with Robert Storr as curator, was named the best monographic museum show in New York City. Another Modern exhibition, ''Mies in Berlin,'' with Terence Riley and Barry Bergdoll as curators, was named best architecture or design show. The Whitney's ''Into the Light: The Projected Image, 1964-77,'' with Chrissie Iles as curator, was named best thematic museum show in New York.
